subject: Re: [junit] How can I get Junit Test to run in parallel threads?
msgSnippet: ... It s not my intent to add kindling, but this brings up a broader issue. You may find it interesting that Enhanced JUnit distributes JUnitPerf. I sure did
messageBody:
Dave Astels wrote:

>On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 16:25, Michael Silverstein wrote:
>
> We have a product called 'Enhanced JUnit' (hence my interest in JUnit
> extensibility issues) that (among other things) will disburse JUnit tests
> across threads, VMs, and CPUs for concurrent execution.
>
>http://www.silvermark.com/Product/enhancedjunit/
>
>Not to start a flame war... but why don't you follow Beck&Gamma's
>example and give it to the JUnit community as so many others have done
>with their extensions?
>
>

It's not my intent to add kindling, but this brings up a broader issue.

You may find it interesting that Enhanced JUnit distributes JUnitPerf.
I sure did when I learned about it... when the product first hit the
streets.

Now don't get me wrong, I'm all about free enterprise. There's no doubt
Enhanced JUnit adds its own bells and whistles over and above the open
source goodies it includes. Indeed, distributing tests across separate
VMs is unique. But Dave's use of the word "community" above struck a
chord with me.

As a member of this community, and the open source community in general,
it got me to thinking about the licenses I use for the stuff I build.
Anything I craft in the future may just be licensed such that
commercial redistribution rights are only available by writing me.
Non-commercial redistribution, and its use in the development of
non-commercial products, will be freely granted. In other words, if I
contribute to this community in good faith, commercial vendors have to
ask before leveraging my wares.

I guess I expected that type of communication would happen naturally
inside of a community. It won't be the first time I've been naive, nor
the last. Live and learn.

Mike

--
Mike Clark
Clarkware Consulting Inc.
http://www.clarkware.com
